title.rendered: Site that sells NFTs of artists like John Lennon or BTS is accused of fraud by the Recording Industry Association of America

content.rendered:
Site that sells NFTs of artists like John Lennon or BTS is accused of fraud by the Recording Industry Association of America

HitPiece is a site that sells music-associated NFTs, which would be built on the Spotify API, offering non-fungible tokens, including song and album items from different artists.

The service caught the attention of some artists who denounced on their social networks that the sale of the NFTs was being carried out without their consent and that it was a scam, for which the site was temporarily closed.

But in addition to the people and musical groups that have declared concern about HitPiece, now the RIAA has also joined, an acronym for the Recording Industry Association of America, who are the ones who are concerned with the certification of record sales in the United States and that asked the site to stop infringing the copyright rules of the music.

The lawsuit was made via a letter to the attorney representing HitPiece, further asking them to provide a full list of the site’s activities and account for all NFTs that have been sold.

“While the operators appear to have taken the main HitPiece site offline for now, this move was necessary to ensure a fair accounting of the damage HitPiece and its operators have already done and to ensure that this site or imitators do not simply resume their scams with another name,” said RIAA legal director Ken Doroshow,

HitPiece, which sold NFTs ranging from the likes of John Lennon to the group BTS, was founded by a former independent record label entrepreneur named Rory Felton, who defended himself in suspending the site, stating that they had clearly hit a nerve and are anxious. for creating the ideal experience for music fans. “To be clear, artists get paid when digital products are sold on Hitpiece. We continue to listen to all user feedback and are committed to evolving the product to fit the needs of artists, labels and fans alike.” the same,” Felton said.
